Because there is more than one neuron in the brain and nerve bundles, if one neuron picks something up and another one doesn't, it can indicate the strength of the stimulus, like being slugged vs. tapped. Also, the cell body does kind of a calculation before "deciding" to send an action potential. A bunch of other neurons feed into its dendrites, and the neurotransmitters they release will  determine how much the cell body polarizes depending on how many are excitatory and how many are inhibitory. But take that with a grain of salt; I'm just a guy on the Internet.

Also, with respect to SNS and PNS, the SNS is actually always active, with the PNS holding the SNS in check. Think of it like being in a car where you always have your foot on both pedals and you lift off the brake. What happens? You shoot forward. Not necessarily the most efficient scenario, but it allows the SNS to respond much faster. In the battle between efficiency and speed of reaction, speed wins.

Great installment to the series, only thing is, saltatory conduction isnt explained clear enough. There's a fast process and a slow process, and the more myelin there is, the less nodes are uncovered, and the FASTER the process is. The nodes are the slow process, and as the charge travels from the cell body to the terminal buttons the charge looses power. The nodes serve to recharge it, but it is a slower process. Smarter brains and neurons have more myelin covering more nodes, so that the times that the impulse is recharged is less but still enough to stay at the action potential. There is another Youtube video on myelin sheaths and saltatory conduction that gave me this information, and anyone wanting to know more about it should watch it. This is so far, out of 26 videos, the only thing that I have found to be potentially misleading and/or confusing. Thank you for the hard work making these videos :)

Psychological diseases are interesting, but you know there's much more to psychology than abnormal (clinical) psychology. There's cognitive psychology (studies attention, memory and perceptions) comparative psychology (studies human like intelligence in nonhumans, typically of primates and sea animals like dolphins and sea lions, as well as birds and elephants), development (sometimes confused with child psychology) and neuropsychology. These are the broader fields, there are others.
